entry.title: Combined summary - Lamport scheme (not signature) to economize on L1
entry.summary:
A recent programming discussion addressed corrections in cryptographic function statements, focusing on mapping LAMPPRI to address and signature formats and omitting earlier nuances. New vulnerabilities were explored through three scenarios: security concerns before a certain block height without data, including address and transaction details after the height, and an adversary outperforming miners with time disadvantages.
LAMPPUB, a fundamental yet unpublished component, may increase in size to ensure negligible collision rates, supporting memory-hard hash functions. The conversation considered varying scenarios - one involving ECCPRI and LAMPPRI mappings to addresses, and another pairing LAMPPRI with LSIG formats, highlighting the importance of completing protocols before attacks. It referenced Boris's approximation on security strength from address size and contemplated a multi-use scheme for LAMPPRI generation to reduce blockchain bloat and enhance security.
Concerns over security model changes related to chain reorganizations and double-spending attacks were discussed, noting that attackers might redirect funds beyond their unspent transaction outputs. The maturity of these funds could widen attack surfaces. To bolster defenses against rainbow table and brute-force attacks, including nonces as salts was suggested, aiming to counteract the underestimation of cracking hashes.
The exchange also debated hash function digest sizes, suggesting they be double the encryption key size, balancing block space utilization with security risks. Cryptographic optimizations discussed included hash sizes, broadcasting ECCPUB alongside LAMPPRI, weakest-link principles, and Schnorr keys benefits, proposing fixed intervals for transaction timings.
The programmers' dialogue delved into securing cryptographic systems and the concept of "key owner broadcasts first bundle" within blockchain technology. It emphasized the security provided by the Lamport chain if it resists attacks better than double-spending exploits. The system's natural resistance to ASIC optimization and the impracticality of attacks despite pessimistic scenarios were noted.
Schnorr signatures' compactness was compared to other formats, and the need for robust bitcoin spending protections was raised. Innovations by R.M. Needham and A. Miller were mentioned, illustrating the evolution of cryptographic methods for digital currency security and efficiency.
Finally, a proposal for byte-efficient Layer 1 (L1) blockchain protocol enhancements was introduced, combining elliptic curve cryptography with a Lamport chain for UTXO freezing and hash preimage publishing. This method could shrink transaction space by requiring only two Lamport hashes instead of a full ECC signature, with Argon2 hashing functions potentially reducing hash sizes further for economical blockchain processing and storage.
